nekton4plankton’s tweets 2012-2024
  • now on bluesky
  • lab website

A twitter archive of @nekton4plankton

Click here to see the R code for creating the below

Repository with the source code: https://github.com/halexand/old_tweets

Forked from: https://github.com/wolfganghuber/tweets

library("jsonlite")
Warning: package 'jsonlite' was built under R version 4.3.3
library("dplyr")
library("stringr")

The file data/tweets.js is in the Twitter archive (zip file) that I downloaded from X. Adapt path to whatever you have.

archivepath = "~/Downloads/twitter-2024-11-19-e227a8ec133c0c3f1e39968f6368f13714013f6080ab344aa62244569484b2bd/data" 
tweets = readLines(file.path(archivepath, "tweets.js")) |>
    sub("^window.YTD.tweets.part0 = ", "", x = _) |>
    fromJSON(flatten = TRUE)

Select tweets and select relevant columns. Here, I chose to drop all retweets and keep all others. Adapt this to your liking.

isrt = grepl("^RT", tweets$tweet.full_text)
out = dplyr::select(tweets[!isrt, ], all_of(c(
  date = "tweet.created_at", 
  text = "tweet.full_text", 
  id = "tweet.id", 
  retweets = "tweet.retweet_count",
  likes = "tweet.favorite_count",
  mediadf = "tweet.entities.media")
))

Some cleanup and prettification: add hyperlinks to URLs and tweet IDs, and sort by date (default: ascending).

out = mutate(out, 
    text = str_replace_all(text, "(https?://\\S+)", "<a href='\\1'>\\1</a>"),
    idhtml = sprintf('<a href="https://x.com/nekton4plankton/status/%s">%s</a>', id, id),
    date = strptime(out$date, "%a %b %d %H:%M:%S %z %Y", tz = "UTC")
) |> arrange(desc(date) )

Deal with media. Tweets that have media associated (images, movies) come with a data.frame in the tweet.entities.media column. We also just go and find all media whose filename contains the tweet ID (see code for ip below) and check consistency.

indir  = file.path(archivepath, "tweets_media")
outdir = "media"
mediafiles = dir(indir)
out$media = character(nrow(out))

if (file.exists(outdir))
  unlink(outdir, recursive = TRUE)
dir.create(outdir)

for (i in seq_len(nrow(out))) {
  m = out$mediadf[[i]]
  if (!is.null(m)) {
    stopifnot(is.data.frame(m), nrow(m) == 1)
    key = tools::file_path_sans_ext(basename(m$media_url))
    im = grep(key, mediafiles)
    ip = grep(paste0("^", out$id[i]), mediafiles)
    if (length(ip) == 0) {
      message(sprintf("%s from tweet #%d not found",  key, i))
    } else {
      #stopifnot(im %in% ip)
      file.copy(file.path(indir, mediafiles[ip]), outdir)
      out$media[i] = paste(
        "::: {.tweet-media}",
        paste(sprintf('![](%s){.lightbox .resized-image}', file.path(outdir, mediafiles[ip])), collapse = "\n"),
        ":::", sep = "\n") 
    }
  }
}

Create the markdown text for each tweet. The main work here is done by the CSS file.

tweetsmd = with(out, sprintf(
'::: {#%s .tweet}
::: {.tweet-header}
<span class="tweet-timestamp">%s Retweets: %s Likes: %s</span>
<span class="tweet-handle">%s</span>
:::  
::: {.tweet-content}
%s
:::  
%s
:::
', id, as.character(date), retweets, likes, idhtml, text, media
))

Inject into the document.

cat(tweetsmd, "\n", sep = "")

2022-04-27 16:05:44 Retweets: 0 Likes: 1 1519347071333064704

We constructed gold standard eukaryotic metaT communities from eukaryotic transcriptomes using jEUKbox (https://t.co/X8TlHfgAvR) and tested various assemblers and co-assembly methods. Read recruitment and assembly stats were improved by integrating info from multiple assemblers. https://t.co/sTYWgYrT5A

We have posted all the eukaryotic and prokaryotic MAGs, which we call TOPAZ (Tara Oceans Particle Associated MAGz) and associated supplementary information on @OSFramework https://t.co/vYX97AmY6L

2021-07-26 19:33:10 Retweets: 0 Likes: 4 1419742610772529166

2021-07-26 19:31:12 Retweets: 0 Likes: 6 1419742116742266882

We also leveraged metagenomic abundance to pull out ecological cohorts of euks + proks – and also potentially associated some host-microbiome type interactions. https://t.co/VV5t66ehou

2021-07-26 19:28:48 Retweets: 0 Likes: 5 1419741511424503808

Additionally, we recovered over 4000 prokaryotic MAGs that were found to be distinct from previous sets of marine bacterial isolate genomes and prior marine MAG recovery efforts– perhaps highlighting the particle associated fraction. https://t.co/godWaROLLJ

2021-07-26 19:26:03 Retweets: 1 Likes: 5 1419740820970737678

As part of the project we developed a random forest model to predict trophic mode of our recovered MAGs as well as a quantitative metric to assess relative heterotrophic-phototrophic inclination. https://t.co/PMJfWD59GC

2021-07-26 19:24:43 Retweets: 0 Likes: 3 1419740483278970881

We developed a pipeline (EukHesit) focused on the recovery of eukaryotic MAGs from metagenomes. We deployed this pipeline on the Tara Oceans large size fraction data to recover over 900 eukaryotic MAGs.

2021-07-15 14:21:01 Retweets: 0 Likes: 0 1415677786937720841

A point that warrants further investigation: estimating pathway completeness in transcriptome based perhaps by leveraging pathway coverage in closely related organisms. I am fairly certain that we are underestimating osmolyte pathways as we were quite stringent.

2021-07-15 14:17:37 Retweets: 0 Likes: 0 1415676931597496321

We also leveraged Tara to look at the expression of these pathways across the global ocean. https://t.co/bwVoFkvm7c

2020-02-20 17:54:58 Retweets: 0 Likes: 0 1230551433671364609

2020-02-20 17:53:48 Retweets: 0 Likes: 0 1230551137507364865

2020-02-20 17:52:18 Retweets: 0 Likes: 0 1230550761429331969

What is more: all these ecotypes coexist in a single drop of seawater.

The question is does this diversity matter in biogeochemical cycles?

2020-02-20 17:00:47 Retweets: 0 Likes: 3 1230537797955534848

2020-02-20 16:59:14 Retweets: 0 Likes: 1 1230537403959406594

The LTER has shown a dominance of the diatom Hemiaulus off the coast in the stratified summer waters!

Chock full of diazotrophs!

A massive DDA bloom! So cool!!!

2020-02-18 19:14:14 Retweets: 0 Likes: 1 1229846602279309312

MVCO currently has 1,011,832,343 images. 4,786,427 have been MANUALLY annotated by Emily Peacock. That is a labor of love.

2020-02-18 19:12:11 Retweets: 0 Likes: 0 1229846089844477952

And now, the timeseries she (and a huge group of others) has been expanded to an official #LTER— the Northeast U.S. Shelf LTER

2020-02-18 19:09:38 Retweets: 0 Likes: 0 1229845444345249793

A huge driver of the widespread use and adoption of IFCB across the field is the associated #OpenSource code. It matters.

2020-02-18 19:07:54 Retweets: 0 Likes: 0 1229845011212034048

Now IFCB might provide a means of early detection for harmful algal blooms (HABs) and has been used all over the US!

2020-02-18 19:05:11 Retweets: 0 Likes: 1 1229844324591947776

The IFCB has even been used to track delicate micrograzers (e.g. ciliates). Work by E Brownlee has shown amazing feeding mechanisms whereby small grazers chow down on huge diatoms.

Can we even maintain the big-eats-little paradigm in oceanography?!

2020-02-18 19:02:21 Retweets: 0 Likes: 2 1229843612357185536

And amazing results from IFCB show a host-parasite seasonal cycles that might be temperature regulated https://t.co/Holyd0LBC6

2020-02-18 19:00:10 Retweets: 0 Likes: 1 1229843063125598208

Trends have also been found in picoeukaryotes that appear to be dividing even faster than Synechococcus and being grazed out. Paper by Bethany Fowler in review.

2020-02-18 18:57:43 Retweets: 0 Likes: 0 1229842448639119361

Trends in Synechococcus https://t.co/mbMrRErsuJ

2020-02-18 18:54:29 Retweets: 0 Likes: 0 1229841634000424962

These instruments have been deployed for more than a decade at MVCO and have provided amazing insights into community dynamics over a decade.

2020-02-18 18:52:39 Retweets: 0 Likes: 0 1229841174229176320

Her hard work (with others) led to the development of the FlowCytoBot and the Imaging FlowCytoBot. Both can be deployed for months at a time and can take high frequency samples.

2020-02-18 18:51:08 Retweets: 0 Likes: 0 1229840792291643392

Thus, much of her work (her whole career, really) has been spent designing automated means of assessing diversity.

2020-02-18 18:48:42 Retweets: 1 Likes: 4 1229840177419313152

The difference between synechococcus and a large diatom is like the difference between a blade of grass and a giant redwood. The diversity matters.

2020-02-18 18:46:27 Retweets: 0 Likes: 0 1229839610072580098

We have many means of measuring phytoplankton at large scale (e.g. satellite ocean color) but it loses the important biological resolution.

2020-02-18 18:44:56 Retweets: 2 Likes: 18 1229839230051815425

2020-01-17 19:27:48 Retweets: 0 Likes: 0 1218253607104995328

Main takeaway: microbiome from different species of ducks not impacted by flu in the same way.

2020-01-17 19:24:28 Retweets: 0 Likes: 0 1218252769452163072

2020-01-17 19:17:06 Retweets: 0 Likes: 0 1218250914147921921

2020-01-17 19:16:02 Retweets: 0 Likes: 1 1218250644408061952

First up: bird flu. Water fowl are a huge reservoir of the flu but don’t get sick (upwards of 40% of flock infected). But they can transfer pathogens to our poultry…

The Antarctic Treaty (drafted December 1, 1959 by 12 countries involved in the International Geophysical Year) was very forward thinking. It specifies in Article III that scientific observations and results made in Antarctica must be ‘made freely available.’ #openscience https://t.co/fC3fV9Z4oo

@studentofwater @WHOI It was originally cut as a diving hole. It became our near-shore training hole– it is very close to the lab. But, yes, careful treading.

📸 by T. Boothby https://t.co/dxTcmdUFER

2018-01-13 20:56:28 Retweets: 6 Likes: 29 952283226848055296

CTD casts are a much different affair on the ice than on ships. Here, students manually lower the CTD down into the ice hole supervised by Instructor Sam Laney from @whoi (not that you can tell given how bundled everyone is). https://t.co/LFbtbZ6JNp

2018-01-11 22:19:49 Retweets: 0 Likes: 0 951579425472118785

@Raphidophyte I have heard of small CTD type devices being adhered to seals and other creatures in other locations. But, here, nope. ;)

2018-01-11 22:11:10 Retweets: 0 Likes: 11 951577248649359362

A note: as soon as these guys show up we must leave. Regulations dictate that wildlife cannot be harassed or interacted with in any way that alters their behavior.

Thus, if seals take up residence in our science hole– it becomes theirs until they decide to leave it.

2018-01-11 21:19:38 Retweets: 1 Likes: 20 951564281782394887

We are drilling holes in the sea ice to access the biology that lies beneath. Unfortunate for doing our science (but fortunate for other reasons) the bigger biology (Weddell seals) really appreciate our efforts.

This guy popped up to get some deep breaths before diving down. https://t.co/lDvjaWFuPV

2018-01-11 04:24:11 Retweets: 0 Likes: 20 951308735279980544

Scientists aren’t the only curious ones around here. A waddle of Adélie penguins came to check out who was making all the noise while we were drilling holes.

I am in awe of how quickly they can scoot along the snow on their bellies. https://t.co/Wdiy3Sq7yx

2018-01-10 19:01:45 Retweets: 1 Likes: 14 951167192602693633

We finally got out on the ice yesterday for the final part of our training (sea ice safety). We learned when it is safe to drive vehicles over cracks in the ice. Though the ice here is incredibly thick (~1.5 m) cracks can still be a hazard. Check the drill used to test thickness. https://t.co/kN4rTVeOpn

We arrived on the ice! Since then, it has been a whirlwind of safety training and orientations. Yesterday, we had an all-day symposium with talks from each of the participants– the diversity of science is phenomenal (exobiology to birds to ocean life). Pic from @jklonthair https://t.co/cWzeF3Aqx2

2018-01-05 19:01:19 Retweets: 0 Likes: 26 949355145749463047

And after some weather delays we are off! We are taking an 8 hr flight on a C-130 down to McMurdo. During the flight you are required to wear all issued Extreme Cold Weather gear. Good thing we have name tags. https://t.co/Y8Lzo6M26t

@rec3141 Do you have Anaconda installed? I would suggest creating a virtual environment with either virtualenv or conda (e.g. conda create –name groopm python=3.5). Then source activate groopm. This will put you into a special environment where you can install all the things you need.
